description.narrative:
UNESCO har inkomit med en ansökan till Sveriges Regionala SRHR Team om stöd på 79 500 000 SEK för insatsen “Our Rights, Our Lives, OUR Future – Making positive sexual and reproductive health and education a reality for adolescents and young people in Sub-Saharan Africa” för perioden 2018-2020.
Insatsen syftar till att stödja allsidig sexual undervisning av god kvalitet som ger unga och unga vuxna egenmakt (empowerment), bygger deras egen agens samt utvecklar färdigheter, kunskap, attityder och kompetenser som behövs för att förebygga hiv, och minska antalet tidiga och oönskade graviditer samt eliminera könsbaserat våld.
Insatsen söker stöd för att arbeta i 10 fokus- och 21 nätverksländer. Fokusländerna från Afrika söder om Sahara regionen inkluderar Kenya, Mocambique, Malawi, South Afrika, Tanzania, Uganda, Cameron, Elfenbenskusten, DRC och Nigeria. Urvalet av nya fokusländer har gjorts genom att prioritera UNAIDS fast-track länder, som har hög hivbörda och en nationell kontext som stödjer implementeringen av allsidig sexualundervisning. Fyra fokusländer från Sveriges regionala SRHR teams finansierade program för allsidig sexualundervisning i östra och södra Afrika är också inkluderade då länderna ännu inte nått målen med antalet elever som tillhandahålls allsidig sexualundervisning av god kvalitet. Instansen kommer att erbjuda intensivt stöd till de 10 fokusländerna för att utföra specifika aktiviteter för att stärka utvecklingen och leveransen av allsidig sexualundervisning baserad på landets specifika behov och situation. De 20 nätverksländerna Benin, Chad, Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Niger, Madagaskar, Mali, Senegal, Togo, Angola, Botswana, Burundi, Etiopien, Namibia, Rwanda, Lesotho, Södra Sudan, Swaziland, Zimbabwe och Zambia kommer att ingå in insatsen och kommer att få uppstartsfinansiering, s.k.seed funding och kommer även att dra nytta av regionala aktiviteter.
UNESCO kommer att implementera insatsen tillsammans med utbildnings-, hälso-, ungdoms-, jämställdhets-, - och civildepartement samt departement för traditionella ledare och departement för lokal utveckling samt nyckelorganisationer inom det civila samhället. Insatsen kommer att använda etablerade plattformar för sammarbete och partnerskap med dessa ministerier på landnivå för att utveckla, implementera och utvärdera program för allsidig sexualundervisning. Den Afrikanska Unionen (AU) och Regionala Ekonomiska Gemenskaperna, dvs. East Africa Community (EAC), Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS), Economic Communities of West African States (ECOWAS) och Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) kommer fortsatt att vara viktiga partners för att säkra politiska åtaganden för en positiv utveckling för unga- och unga vuxnas hälsa.

UNESCO has applied to Sweden's Regional SRHR Team for funding of 79,500,000 SEK to carry out an intervention entitled ''Our Rights, Our Lives, Our Future - Making positive sexual and reproductive health and education outcomes a reality for adolescents and young people in Sub-Saharan Africa " during the period 2018-2020.
The intervention intends to support delivery of good quality comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) that empowers adolescents and young people, and builds agency while developing the skills, knowledge, attitudes and competencies required for preventing HIV, reducing early and unintended pregnancies and eliminating gender based violence.
The intervention proposes to work with 10 focus and 21 networking countries. The focus countries, from SSA region will include Kenya, Mozambique, Malawi, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, Cameroon, Côte d’Ivoire, DRC and Nigeria. Selection of new focus countries has been based on prioritizing UNAIDS Fast Track countries, with a high HIV burden and a national environment supportive of CSE delivery. Four focus countries from Sweden's SRHR Regional team's funded CSE programme in ESA are also included as they are yet to reach the target numbers of learners benefitting from good quality CSE. The project will offer intensive support to the ten focus countries to carry out specific activities to strengthen the development and delivery of comprehensive sexuality education based on the specific needs and situation of each country. Twenty one networking countries - Benin, Chad, Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Niger, Madagascar, Mali, Senegal, Togo, Angola, Botswana, Burundi, Ethiopia, Namibia, Rwanda, Lesotho, South Sudan, Swaziland, Zimbabwe and Zambia will be part of the intervention and will receive seed funding and benefit from common regional activities.
UNESCO will implement this intervention together with Ministries of education, health, youth, gender, chiefs, traditional affairs, community development and family affairs as well as civil society organisations. The project will draw on existing platforms of collaboration and partnerships with those ministries at country level to support the designing, implementing and monitoring of CSE programmes. The African Union and Regional Economic Communities (RECs), i.e. East Africa Community (EAC), Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS), Economic Communities of West African States (ECOWAS) and Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) will continue to be key partners for supporting political commitment towards positive health outcomes for adolescents and young people.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative:
Summary of results for 2020: Objective 1 - Secure and sustain strong political commitment and support for adolescents and young peoples access to comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) and SRH services across SSA
From the onset of this intervention, UNESCO has sought to garner political commitment from countries to prioritise CSE programming and implementation through Ministries of Education and Health. In Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) this was done through the ESA Ministerial Commitment . In 2013, the ESA Commitment brought together Ministries of Education and Health from 20 countries to strengthen HIV prevention efforts and foster positive health outcomes by advocating for access to quality, comprehensive sexuality education as well as sexual and reproductive health services for young people in the region. This commitment was reaffirmed in 2016 and came to an end in December 2020.
Key result for this year are: -UNESCO, in collaboration with the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) Secretariat, the East African Community (EAC), and other members of the Commitments Technical Coordinating Group (TCG), commissioned an evaluation to assess progress and achievements of the ESA Commitment (2013-2020) against its targets and generate knowledge and evidence that will inform its extension to 2030, in alignment with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. -UNESCO collaborated with governments and partners across ESA Commitment member states to convene national consultations to review country progress, discuss unfinished business, and explore the extension of the Commitment. By the end of 2020 national consultations had been convened in Botswana, Ethiopia, Malawi, South Sudan, Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.
In West and Central Africa, UNESCO together with other partners is seeking to secure a similar commitment to accelerate CSE Programming and Implementation in the region. Key results for this year are: -The WCA Technical Working Group (TWG) completed data collection from each country involved in the WCA Commitment process and developed 24 country fact sheets on health, education and gender issues. -National consultations, jointly led by ministries of education and health, were conducted in nine countries, bringing together a wide range of stakeholders from government, civil society, community and traditional leadership, as well as representatives of adolescents and youth. The main objective of the consultations was to collect substantive recommendations from stakeholders to strengthen sexuality education, SRH services, SGBV prevention, and protection for AYP. During the process, stakeholders were able to review and validate the country data on the situation of AYP, propose specific recommendations to address the needs of AYP at country level, propose key messages for the formulation of the WCA Commitment, and develop a country-level road map for stakeholder engagement in the Commitment process. - A regional report on the situation of AYP in WCA was also undertaken to provide an evidence base for the Commitment and support advocacy. The report focuses on education, SRH, gender, and other important issues affecting AYP of both sexes, and will be launched in 2021 and presented at a regional consultation for the WCA Commitment.
Other key results - Finalization of the Our Talks Parent Child Communication (PCC) manual, which seeks to support healthy and positive communication between parents/guardians and AYP on SRHR. In addition to the manual, an implementation guide and a monitoring tool were also developed. By the end of 2020, Botswana, Eswatini, Namibia, and Malawi had managed to roll out implementation, commencing with the recruitment and training of CSOs to conduct community interventions with parents/guardians and AYPs. - In 2019, UNESCO collaborated with World Council of Churches (WCC) to develop a toolkit for religious leaders on CSE and SRHR. The toolkit was finalized in 2020, whereupon UNESCO partnered with a CSE expert to develop handouts and factsheets that are intended to assist religious leaders in addressing SRHR issues within their congregations and communities. Trainings with religious leaders are planned for 2021, given these did not take place in 2020 due to ban of public gatherings as part of the COVID-19 pandemic containment measures.
Unexpected results - Successful adaptation of the Lets Talk! campaign on Elimination of Unintended Pregnancies to Lets Talk at Home in response to COVID-19 restrictions. With school closures, UNESCO had to immediately adjust activities to virtual platforms. A radio drama and key messages around the concept Lets Talk at Home were developed and disseminated. The radio mini-drama series was aired on national radio stations in the campaign focus countries, reaching at least 18 million listeners. In addition, six webinars were convened to reach a broader number of young people and ignite conversations on different approaches to facilitate dialogue between parents/guardians and adolescents on and around SRHR in general, and EUP in particular. A total of 283 participants attended the webinar sessions and 417,310 people were reached through social media (387,103 through Facebook, 16,833 through Instagram, and 13,324 through Twitter). -Launch of Let's Talk Period- A digital campaign on Menstrual hygiene management (MHM). UNESCO, together with partner agencies within the framework of the French Muskoka Fund and led by UNFPA and UNICEF, organized this regional digital communication campaign on MHM in WCA with the aims of informing, influencing,and engaging young people in the region around the issues of MHM, as well as challenging taboos. The campaign was launched at an event on the International Day of the Girl Child on 11 October with the objective of highlighting the situation faced by adolescent girls and women in the region in relation to MHM and to share experiences in countries where MHM interventions are implemented. The event mobilized 115 participants from different organizations, including UN agencies, CSOs, universities, governmental cooperation, and development agencies, and provided a platform for a first look at the main issues of advocacy as well as the themes to be explored during the campaign and a regional symposium on MHM. UNESCO supported the production of campaign materials including a mini online site, 21 infographics (adapted for both Facebook and Twitter), two animations, and 10 videos for different countries in the region. Between the launch in October and the end of January 2021, 198 Twitter posts had been published, with 515 retweets and 1,198 likes. On Facebook, 101 posts received 1,016 likes, 16,966 shares, and 2,533 comments. Apart from this, a web-series was produced, with 10 episodes on the theme of MHM that will begin broadcasting in March 2021.
Objective 2 -Deliver accurate, rights-based and good quality CSE programmes that provide the knowledge, attitudes, and skills essential for gender equality, safer behaviours, and reduced adolescent pregnancy
UNESCO focused on finalizing the standardized in-service CSE training package for teachers; reviewing and improving the CSE online course; training of teachers on CSE; developing a coaching and mentoring strategy to provide ongoing support to trained teachers in the delivery of good quality CSE; delivering CSE through a smartphone application; and finalizing a new version of the Sexuality Education Review and Analysis Tool (SERAT). The SERAT, while a tool for assessing sexuality education programmes at primary and secondary levels education, also contains a dedicated section to assess national laws and policies with 35 indicators, such as minimum legal age of marriage, criminalization of GBV, and the degree to which the legislation protects SRHR
Key results under this objective for the period under review: - The programme acceleration countries contributed nearly half (43%) of the 51 817 394 young people in and out of school reached with CSE through various media platforms. Of the primary and secondary schools that reported to be providing sexuality education, 49.5% (30 260) were in four programme acceleration countries namely Eswatini, Malawi, Tanzania and Zambia. This achievement was due to the programme acceleration approach, where increased financial and technical support enabled countries to swiftly respond to disruptions to education as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, and ensure continuity of learning and access to CSE. - Following the pilot of the regional In-Service teacher training package (in service CSE module) in 2019 by 84 ministries of health and education specialists, teacher educators, curriculum developers, and select civil society representatives across the ESA region, UNESCO successfully finalised this module in the period under review. The package includes scripted lesson plans, scripted radio lessons, charts and presentations, and CSE AMAZE videos and is made up of different core sessions, where a description of each session is provided, as well as notes to the facilitator, and the total time, materials, and resources required. Given the importance of the local context within which sexuality education is delivered, the package is adaptable for country's individual needs. - As part of efforts to reach larger numbers of teachers with training on CSE, UNESCO embarked on a process of institutionalizing the in-service online teacher training course at country level. In the period under review, UNESCO conducted a review and revision of the CSE online course to integrate key content from the regional in-service teacher training package, integrate formative and summative assessment activities that are more meaningful for the teachers, and improve the flow of sessions so that each activity is linked to the next. The CSE online course will be hosted on the CSE Learning Platform and will now be offered to teachers free of charge. - Numbers of Teacher trained in the year 2020 was a total of 10,975 in-service teachers in Cameroon, Cote dIvoire, Ghana, Ethiopia, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mali, Namibia, Nigeria, Senegal, South Sudan, Tanzania, Togo and Zambia. In addition, UNESCO provided support towards production and dissemination of teaching and learning materials. For example, in Tanzania, at least 500 copies of CSE teaching and learning material, including training manuals and teaching aids (posters) were disseminated. In South Sudan, copies of the CSE teacher training manual for teachers were also disseminated, including a video in sign language. In WCA, support for delivery of CSE included technical support for the development of an online teaching and learning platform in Cameroon, an online teacher training module in Nigeria, the development of CSE competency frameworks and training manuals in Cote dIvoire, and validation of 12 student manuals and three teachers guides in DRC. - Development of a regional coaching and mentorship strategy based on the need for ongoing teacher support and supervision of CSE delivery (needs assessment on CSE curriculum development and implementation across 15 sub-Saharan Africa (SSA)countries was conducted in 2019). The coaching and mentoring strategy describes differing approaches to supporting teachers through coaching and mentoring, prompts critical reflection, and offers recommendations to inform strategies for coaching and mentoring at the country level. - In order to further deepen the evidence-base on CSE in relation to the needs of young people with disabilities in the school system, UNESCO implemented a needs assessment in five countries (namely Eswatini, Malawi, Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe). The needs assessment found that some of the barriers to the delivery of CSE for children and young people with disabilities in school settings are generic and pertinent to the delivery of CSE to all children, irrespective of disability. The assessment further found that delivery of CSE to children and young persons with disabilities is largely considered by stakeholders to be better in specialist provision, such as special needs schools, where teachers are more equipped to adapt resources and tailor their approach. The lack of skills among teachers in mainstream settings, often adopting a one size fits all approach, emphasizes the urgent need to strengthen the overall teacher capacity for working with learners with disabilities. - Successful launch of the French-language mobile application called Hello Ado by UNESCO and partners. This was created to address the challenge of reaching the large population under the age of 24 in WCA with CSE and SRHR information. The app uses games to reinforce knowledge and attitudes about health and wellness. Hello Ado also contains a directory of nearly 3,000 health, protection, and legal and judicial support services across eight countries in the region, to which users are directed based on their needs and location. In addition, an emergency function helps to quickly identify users to services responding to crisis situations. Since the launch of its beta version in May 2020, Hello Ado has already achieved significant results, with more than 1,000 AYP having accessed the app and many youth organizations interacting with their members via the app as well .
Objective 3 - Support delivery of safer, healthier, and inclusive school and community environments for all young people
Main efforts to promote safer and inclusive school in 2020 included the implementation and finalization of the CwR tool pilot; training of teachers on School Related Gender Based Violence (SRGBV); and support to the education sector in its response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Key results under this objective for the period under review: -UNESCO implemented a pilot of the Connect with Respect (CwR)curriculum-based tool for addressing SRGBV across four ESA countries, namely Eswatini, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The pilot was mainly focused on content and delivery of the programme, as well as on indicating the programmes relevance, effectiveness, and impact. While 18 schools, 1,740 learners, and 84 teachers participated in the pilot in Eswatini and 24 schools, 2,400 students, and 84 teachers participated in Zambia, in Tanzania only a pre-intervention survey was conducted with 50 schools and 4,700 learners, and in Zimbabwe, the pilot was cut short after the pre-intervention data collection due to school closures as a result of COVID-19. Results from the pilot in Eswatini showed that the CwR programme is relevant for secondary schools and that the activities are effective in increasing knowledge and understanding of gender and social norms, as well as developing positive gender attitudes influencing behaviour change. The Zambia pilot revealed that the CwR programme had significant impact on teacher confidence and competence, with over 87% of the teachers reporting that the programme had given them a new and dynamic view of discipline and service rendering. In addition, they reported that following the delivery of the CwR programme, they felt more respected by the learners, thus boosting their confidence. Further, it was noted that students attitudes towards GBV and help-seeking behaviours after experiencing GBV had changed for the better. Students reported that they had gained a wider knowledge on the issues related to GBV and were able to now question some harmful norms and practices. -Significant progress was made on sensitizing community members, including parents/ guardians, on CSE and SRHR and in developing the capacity of religious and traditional leaders to advocate for and support AYPs access to CSE and SRHR services through a wide range of activities in 2020. Over 27 million community stakeholders, including chiefs, opinion leaders, women leaders, youth leaders, and other community members were reached through face-to-face engagement, and media platforms. - Another intervention successfully implemented in 2020 was the training of 1,536 teachers from 243 schools in Senegal and Togo on understanding the forms and effects of SRGBV; mastering concrete prevention and response measures through active pedagogical approaches; implementing positive discipline; mechanisms for detection; and reporting, counselling, support, and referral of situations of violence or abuse recorded in ad around schools. Further training of teachers will be conducted in 2021. - In response to Covid19, UNESCO also used its comparative advantage to reach out with initiatives to ensure that children, adolescents, and young people understood basic, age-appropriate information about COVID-19, including its symptoms, how it is transmitted, how to prevent transmission, and how to cope with its impact; re-orient the O3 programme to use digital channels and low-tech solutions such as TV and radio to ensure continuity of learning and access to SRH information; and provided support towards safe school re-opening. Specifically, UNESCO developed a series of videos for learners on coping with COVID-19, which focus on dealing with anxiety, exam preparation, and keeping safe after lockdown. In Cameroon, a series of micro-programmes was produced with the purpose of highlighting the need for heightened diligence in preventing EUPs, HIV and other STIs, along with taking measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The videos were disseminated nationally, reaching 500,000 viewers. Digital spaces and social media have proved to be an effective means to educate young people with this same type of information during school closures in Ghana and Nigeria too, where 100,000 and 5 million people respectively were reached through online platforms. - UNESCO supported the development of eLearning and distance learning solutions to ensure continuity of learning during the lockdowns in other countries as well. For example, in Zimbabwe, UNESCO collaborated with the Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education (MoPSE) and the Zimbabwe Schools Examinations Council (ZIMSEC) to develop an innovative WhatsApp-based chatbot learning initiative for disseminating educational resources to learners. The chatbot, dubbed Dzidzo Paden/ Imfundwendlini, provides on-demand access to educational materials for students including exam tips, past exam papers, and marking schemes that cater for current examination classes, namely Grade 7, Form 4, and Form 6. In Zambia, UNESCO supported the launch of the national eLearning (https://elearning. co.zm/) and Smart Revision (https://www.smartrevision.co.zm/) portals, which provide teaching and learning through electronic educational content for early childhood education, primary, secondary, youth and adult literacy education and revision content for examination classes (Grades 7, 9, and 12), respectively.
Unexpected results: -UNESCO partnered with UNFPA and MIET AFRICA to use radio to mitigate the devastating impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on communities in Lesotho, Malawi, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. The partnership resulted in the development of three Youth Talk radio programmes to support the health, well-being, and SRH of young people as a result of increased vulnerability due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Furthermore, UNESCO purchased solar powered radios for distribution in rural settings to promote access to both the Youth Talk radio programmes and educational lessons broadcast via radio in the four countries. - UNESCO and partners in Côte dIvoire and Nigeria led research to understand the impact of COVID-19 on AYP in terms of their access to learning, evolving household situations, and exposure to violence, while in Cameroon, learners were surveyed to highlight their perceptions of the pandemic, their apprehensions about the re-opening of schools, their health and well-being needs during the COVID-19 period, and their academic concerns. - UNESCO supported ministries of education to develop their respective national guidelines for re-opening of schools after lockdown, whereupon guidelines were developed in Botswana, Eswatini, South Africa, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Similarly, in Cameroon, a framework for the re-opening of schools, prepared by UNESCO and partners in the global coalition for education, was transmitted to the MoE and training was conducted for a return to school in the best conditions of hygiene and protection.
Objective 4 -Strengthen the evidence base on CSE and safer school environments
To pursue this objective, UNESCO commissioned several pieces of work such as a study on attitudes and perceptions on CSE; implementation of a midterm evaluation of the Regional Lets Talk campaign, and finalized and launched the CSE Learning Platform. Key results under this objective for the period under review: - Successfully commissioned a qualitative study on attitudes, perceptions, and experiences of learners and teachers on CSE across six countries (Botswana, Eswatini, Ghana, Malawi, Uganda, and Zambia). The objectives of the study were not only to understand the attitudes, perceptions, and experiences of learners and teachers on CSE, but also to examine community members knowledge, attitudes and perceptions on CSE, identify the factors that affect or influence the delivery of CSE, and examine linkages, if any, between schools and health facilities. Results of this study found that the learners had positive attitudes towards learning CSE due to the perceived benefits and relevance to their own lives, such as acquiring knowledge and skills for HIV and EUP prevention and handling of peer relationships. Learners did, however, have concerns about the capacities of teachers to deliver CSE topics, ranging from clarity of content to consistency and depth of information, citing reasons such as some teachers being shy or embarrassed by the topics and others not giving adequate explanations and rushing through the topics. Another important issue the study illustrated was that learners with disabilities who are enrolled in mainstream schools have limited access to CSE due to lack of specialized teachers and learning or teaching aids. By end of 2020, the study had been completed in Uganda and Zambia. In 2021, the study will be completed in the remaining four countries. - Mid-term evaluation of the Regional Lets Talk campaign was conducted in order to assess the campaigns effectiveness and audience reception, as well as generate lessons to inform and refine the campaign in the remaining term. UNESCO, together with the Lets Talk! campaign partners, namely UNFPA, the Southern Africa HIV and AIDS Information Dissemination Service (SAfAIDS), and Save the Children, collaborated with Research and Training for Health and Development (RTHD) to implement the evaluation, which was conducted in Malawi, South Africa, and Uganda. The evaluation found that the campaign: the campaign helped concretize the magnitude of Eliminating Unintended Pregnancies (EUP) by putting figures and data on the problem in the region, drawing the attention of policy makers and politicians; raised awareness and discussion on EUP through participation by influential policy-makers and community members; has provided an entry point for advocating for the adoption of CSE as a way to reduce EUP; has provided important insights about the negative implications of EUP on the economy and positive ways for getting it under control; has helped influence positive reporting on EUP (previously, many media channels reported on EUP with a bias towards victim-blaming, stigma, and discrimination). - Finalisation and successfully launching of the CSE Learning Platform, a web-based platform that facilitates knowledge exchange across programme countries. The platform has a digital library with over 300 resources, such as CSE frameworks, CSE curricula, and CSE teaching and learning materials. The learning platform seeks to connect a wide range of different stakeholders in promoting the health and well-being of AYP, including policy-makers, curriculum developers, pre- and in-service teachers, health workers, religious leaders, traditional leaders, parents/guardians, and other community members. - Initiation of a regional study on the situation of AYP in WCA to provide an evidence base for the WCA Commitment and support advocacy. The study will be launched in 2021 and presented at a regional CSO consultation for the WCA Commitment. - Launching of the updated version of the Sexuality Education Review and Analysis Tool (SERAT 3.0), aligned to the 2018 revised version of the UN International Technical Guidance on Sexuality Education (ITGSE), and applied it in two WCA countries (Senegal and Togo). SERAT 3.0 will serve as an invaluable resource to inform debate and advocacy by making available data on sexuality education that is understandable, easy to analyse, and accessible to different audiences.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
